Harbin 150080 China With the aim of green chemistry and sustainable development, the coupling of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonate is an attractive and promising CO2 fixation without byproducts. Solvent- and metal-free heterogeneous catalysts offer an environmentally friendly and convenient separation alternative to traditional metal-based or homogeneous catalysts. Hence, hydrolyzed carbon nitride (HCN) was successfully synthesized via urea-derived carbon nitride (CN) hydrolyzed in NaOH solution and the freeze-drying (FD) method was adopted to obtain the HCN-FD catalyst. The composition and chemical properties of HCN-FD were thoroughly characterized by different analysis methods. The synergistic effects of hydrogen-bond donors of –COOH, –OH and –NHX in HCN-FD resulted in improved acidity sites characterized by NH3-TPD. Compared with CN, HCN-FD combined with tetrabutylammonium iodide cocatalyst displayed satisfactory catalytic performance in the CO2 cycloaddition due to more exposed active sites (–COOH, –OH and –NHX). Moreover, the recyclability and versatility of the HCN-FD catalyst were excellent in CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Thus, the HCN-FD catalyst was a potential candidate for the practical utilization of CO2 fixation due to its advantage of facile synthetic method, inexpensive raw material and environmental friendliness. Introduction Human being's requirement depends on fossil-fuel-based energy, resulting in excessive CO2 emissions into the atmosphere, which is believed to be the culprit of the greenhouse effect [1,2]. Nevertheless, CO2 is considered as an environmentally benign, abundant sustainable and ideal C1 building block. Furthermore, it is a significantly meaningful strategy to synthesize valuable organic products with CO2 substrate [3]. Whereas, CO2 conversion is limited by its kinetic inertness and thermodynamic stability due to the most oxidized form of carbon [4]. On one hand, thermodynamic stability can be addressed via reacting with high-energy substrates such as epoxide [5]. Particularly, it is attractive due to a green and atom-economic route to synthesize cyclic carbonates. Moreover, cyclic carbonates offer wide and practical applications as polar aprotic solvents, organic synthesis intermediates and electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries [6]. Hence, plenty of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic systems have been generally explored for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. Although homogeneous catalytic system such as ionic liquid [7,8] and metal salen [9] present outstanding catalytic performance, it is inescapable drawbacks in separation, purification and reuse, which limit their general applications. As a result, functionalized organic polymers [10,11], metal organic frameworks [12-14], covalent organic frameworks [15], silica-based material [16,17] and graphite carbon nitride (CN) [18] are served as heterogeneous catalysts in the CO2 cycloaddition. As one of the heterogeneous catalysts, CN has received widespread attentions in CO2 capture [19,20] and conversion [21,22] due to its good chemical stability, readily available source and environmentally friendly nature. Furthermore, CN endows with nitrogen-rich structures (tri-s-triazine ring, –NH2, –NH–), which play the key roles as the hydrogen bond donor (HBD) active sites to activate the epoxides through hydrogen bonds [23], Furthermore, the existence of uncondensed amines in CN can adsorb and activate CO2 [24]. Unfortunately, pristine CN provides poor activity in CO2 cycloaddition. Hence, many efforts have been devoted to CN-modification to enhance catalytic performance including increasing surface area [25], element doping [26], and ionic liquid modified CN [27] and so on. Zhao's group developed a series of boron-doped carbon nitride supported on mesoporous SBA-15 (BCN/SBA-15) via one-step synthesis, and B0.1CN/SBA-15 presented the optimum catalytic activity at 97.8% propylene carbonate (PC) yield under the conditions of 130 °C, 3 MPa and 24 h [28]. Xu et al. developed hydroxyl‑functionalized CN through simple HCl treatment, which was applied in CO2 cycloaddition with propylene oxide. The hydroxyl groups of CN−OH served as HBD in catalyzing the reaction and 60% PC yield was achieved at 140 °C for 6 h with DMF solvent [29]. Furthermore, carbon nanofiber-supported BiCl3@Bi@CN catalyst was prepared via electrospinning technology and high-temperature calcination [30]. The bifunctional catalyst contained acid-base active sites, which could not only activate CO2 via metal ion but also offered nucleophiles and HBD to active epoxides through the synergistic effects. 87.9% epichlorohydrin was converted at 140 °C, 2 MPa for 4 h. Unsatisfactorily, at present the CO2 fixation still needs to be carried out with the modified CN catalyst to achieve satisfactory yield under the harsh conditions (>130 °C, or long time, and need of additional solvent). Considering the above, it is meaningful to synthesize an efficient modification-CN catalyst for the CO2 coupling reaction under milder conditions. According to pioneering work, the investigation on CO2 cycloaddition with epoxide has shown that ring-opening of epoxide is the rate-determining step [31]. In general, two strategies, containing Lewis acid metal ion and HBD such as –COOH, –OH, –NHX, have been employed to promote epoxide activation. Meanwhile, the presence of nucleophile can accelerate the ring-opening due to its attack on the less sterically hindered β-C atom of epoxides [32]. As well known, it is not neglected for the drawback of metal leaching and the risk of environmental pollution. In this regard, through hydrolysis of carbon nitride by NaOH, hydrolyzed carbon nitride (HCN) with metal-free and HBD groups was developed, which was rich in amino, hydroxyl and carboxyl groups. Additionally, two HCN catalysts were obtained via different drying methods and the structure and properties were characterized. The nucleophilic agent tetrabutylammonium iodide (Bu4NI) was employed to help the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides. As a result of the synergistic interactions between the catalyst and Bu4NI cocatalyst, the CO2 cycloaddition with propylene oxide exhibited efficient conversion under the conditions of 110 °C and 2.0 MPa within 6 h. Besides, the as-prepared HCN catalyst provided good reusability and broad substrate compatibility, which featured with simple, green, low-cost preparation method. All chemicals were used directly without further purification. Characterizations instruments The crystallinity of the as-prepared samples was recorded by XRD on Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffraction. FT-IR spectra were recorded by using a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer with standard KBr pellet in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. XPS was identified by Thermo Fisher Scientic Escalab 250Xi instrument. Element analysis (EA) was characterized by Vario MICRO cube CHN analyzer. The NH3 temperature-program desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted on TP-5080, which was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector automatic adsorption instrument. First, 100 mg of the catalyst was treated in helium gas (30 mL min−1) for 30 min at 300 °C to remove moisture and other impurities. Then, when the temperature was cooled down to room temperature, the NH3 adsorption process was conducted by exposing the catalyst to NH3 using a stream of 30 mL min−1 for 45 min at 25 °C. The catalyst was then flushed with helium again until the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signals achieved a stable baseline. Finally, the catalyst was heated in the presence of a helium stream between 200 °C and 500 °C, with a ramping rate of 10 °C min−1, to obtain NH3-TPD profiles. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared FT-IR spectra was recorded on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 FT-IR instrument. Synthesis of HCN catalyst Firstly, pristine CN was prepared through one-step thermal polymerization urea in a muffle furnace under the temperature programmed with a rate of 2.3 °C min−1 and heated from room temperature to 550 °C. The muffle furnace was maintained at 550 °C for 4 h, the light-yellow powder was collected and then grinded. Subsequently, 500 mg of CN solid was dispersed in 20 mL NaOH solution (3 mol L − 1) and then refluxed at 60 °C for 12 h under vigorous stirring. Afterwards, the mixture was ultrasonic washed with deionized water and centrifuged until the mixture was no precipitation. Then, the mixture was rinsed by excess HNO3 (1 mol L − 1) to remove the residue NaOH. Similarly, it was ultrasonic washed with deionized water and centrifuged until the mixture was no precipitation. Finally, the powder was obtained via freeze-drying for 48 h under the vacuum of −60 °C, which was denoted as HCN-FD. Moreover, the control HCN-TD catalyst was obtained directly by traditional drying at 60 °C in oven for 12 h. The possible structure was shown in Fig. 1 A, and the three catalysts were exhibited in Fig. 1B. Catalytic evaluation CO2 cycloaddition with propylene oxide (PO) to propylene carbonate (PC) was carried out in a stainless-steel autoclave reactor (50 mL) equipped with a magnetic stirrer. Typically, the catalyst (100 mg), cocatalyst (0.3 mmol) and PO (34.5 mmol) were placed in the stainless-steel autoclave with inner Teflon-lining. Afterwards, the autoclave was heated to 110 °C and pressurized with CO2 to 2.0 MPa for reaction within 6 h. When the reaction was completed, the reactor was cooled in an ice-water bath and extra CO2 was released gradually. The solution was diluted with ethyl acetate and analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent GC-7890Ainstrument) equipped with FID with HP-5 capillary column (19091J-413) using the carrier gas N2. The spent catalyst was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethyl acetate (4 mL × 5) to remove the residue cocatalyst. Then the catalyst was dried at 60 °C for 12 h, and reused for the next run and the fresh cocatalyst was added in each cycle. Results and discussion Catalyst characterizations XRD was performed to examine the crystallinity of the as-prepared catalyst, and the results were exhibited in Fig. 2 A. All the samples presented intensive diffraction peaks at 27.5°, which was indexed to the graphitic interlayer stacking structure (002) plane. Simultaneously, the small diffraction peak located at 12.9° was assigned to the in-planar structural packing (100) plane tri-s-triazine units, which formed one-dimension melon strands [33,34]. Moreover, a shift peak at 12.6° appeared at HCN-TD and HCN-FD, owing to the change of in-planar structural packing after NaOH hydrolysis. The peak intensity at 12.6° significantly weakened after NaOH treatment, resulting from the loss or change of structures within the structure [35]. Moreover, the detailed chemical structures of all samples were tested by FT-IR spectroscopy. As shown in FT-IR spectra in Fig. 2B, a broad peak during 3700−3000 cm−1 could be ascribed to −OH and –NH/−NH2 [36,37]. Furthermore, the major peaks during 1200−1700 cm−1 was assigned to the stretching vibrations of the N–C = N heterorings [34,38]. However, for the pristine CN, the peak at 813 cm−1 belonged to tri-s-triazine ring [26], while the strong band at 798 cm−1 was related to the bending vibration of the tri-s-triazine ring for HCN-FD and HCN-TD [39]. The shifts in the peak after NaOH treating were possibly associated with the increase of –OH and –COOH in CN [40]. In addition, the detailed chemical structures of CN, HCN-TD and HCN-FD were revealed by XPS measurement. As represented in Fig. 3 A, the XPS survey spectra proved the signals of C, N and O elements in all the samples. The high resolution scans in Fig. 3B showed C 1 s peaks of pristine CN at 284.6 eV and 288.2 eV, respectively corresponding to the C–C and N–C = N [41]. For HCN-TD and HCN-FD, three bonding states of carbon species were divided, centered at 284.6, 286.2 and 288.2 eV. The peaks at around 284.6 eV and 288.2 eV could be assigned to the C–C and N–C = N/N–C = O [41,42]. Notably, the new signals at 286.2 eV belonged to the C–O/C–N unit, which was possibly originated from –COOH (–C–OH) or C–NH after NaOH treating the CN structure [39,43]. Meanwhile, the intensity ratio of C–C together with C–O/C–N bonds to the total C in the HCN-TD and HCN-FD increased from 0.129 to 0.546 or 0.619, which was responsible for the formation of C–O and C–NH2 bonds (Table 1 ) [39]. Moreover, all samples exhibited the three characteristic peaks in N 1 s spectra (Fig. 3C). The peak at about 398.7 corresponded to the C–N = C (N2C) bonds originated from tri-s-triazine. The other peaks at 399.8 and about 400.9 were due to tertiary nitrogen N–(C)3 (N3C) and N in –NH2 or –NH (–NHX) [41]. Nevertheless, compared with CN, the relative amounts of NHX in HCN-TD and HCN-FD according to the peak area presented a decreasing trend varied from 0.515 to 0.075 and 0.515 to 0.113, respectively (Table 1). This result indicated that some terminal amino groups were replaced. Also, Table 1 revealed that the contents of N3C and N2C declined in HCN-TD and HCN-FD, whereas, the area ratio of N3C and N2C in both samples increased compared with pristine CN, indicating that parts of tri-s-triazine structures were destroyed via NaOH hydrolysis [39]. Fig. 3D displayed O 1 s high-resolution XPS spectra of CN, HCN-TD and HCN-FD samples. For the CN sample, only one peak at 532.8 eV belonged to the adsorbed moisture from the air [35]. Compared with CN, O 1 s spectrum of HCN-TD revealed three types of electron orbits at binding energies of 531.8, 532.8 and 533.3 eV, respectively attributed to C = O, adsorbed H2O or C–C = O, –C–OH [39,44,45]. Also, O1s XPS spectrum of HCN-FD was similar to HCN-TD. Especially, the increased intensity at 533.3 eV in HCN-FD was responsible for the increase in O content resulted from the substituted amino groups (Table 1). To further determine the contents of various element contents, EA characterization was performed (Table 2 ). In contrast to the pristine CN, the C and N mass percentages of HCN-TD and HCN-FD decreased while H contents increased, which might be because the structure of CN was hydrolyzed into –COOH and –OH, resulting in the changes of various contents. Furthermore, the C/N ratio of HCN-TD and HCN-FD exhibited slightly higher than CN, illustrating the amine groups/tri-s-triazine possibly were destroyed after NaOH treating leading to the partial N loss [46], consistent with the results of C 1 s and N 1 s XPS spectra. Moreover, the O element contents increased, suggesting that –COOH and –OH were generated due to the NaOH treating, in accordance with XRD and FT-IR results. To further investigate the acidic properties of the catalysts, NH3-TPD was investigated in Fig. 4 . As shown, no desorption peak was found for CN, because it was a base material with abundant basic sites (–NH2 and –NH). In contrast to CN, the desorption peak around 450 °C in HCN-FD indicated to the acid strength was increased due to the introduction of –OH and –COOH by NaOH treatment [47]. Similarly, strong acid was also introduced in HCN-TD, but its acid amount was lower than HCN-FD. In addition, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for CN, HCN-TD and HCN-FD samples were evaluated and exhibited in Fig. 4B. The as-prepared CN sample exhibited typical mesoporous type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops and the specific surface area of CN was 106 m2 g − 1. Unfortunately, the specific surface area of HCN-TD and HCN-FD were very low which was possibly due to the collapse of pore structure resulted from the hydrolysis by NaOH. Although the specific surface area of HCN-TD and HCN-FD remarkably decreased after NaOH hydrolysis, the acidity increase of HCN-TD and HCN-FD was beneficial to the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. SEM and TEM were carried out to characterize the morphology and microstructure of these above samples and shown in Fig. 5 . The SEM images in Fig. 5A revealed that CN had a plane-stacked structure. However, HCN-TD and HCN-FD presented bulk morphologies. Moreover, TEM images (Fig. 5B) clearly showed CN was endowed with irregular sheets, HCN-TD exhibited smooth surface. For the HCN-FD, bulk structure with abundant pores was formed, resulted from freezing-drying process. Activities of various catalysts for cycloaddition reaction With these above-synthesized three catalysts of CN, HCN-TD and HCN-FD, the cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO) to form propylene carbonate (PC) was further investigated (Table 3 ). Give the long-term and sustainable aim in CO2 cycloaddition by implementing the merit of minimalism (low temperature, practical time frames, low pressure of CO2, low catalyst loadings and solvent- and metal-free conditions), the catalytic activities of three catalysts under gently mild reaction conditions (100 °C) were evaluated. In the three catalysts, the active sites of organic amine were mainly –NH and –NH2. According to the CHN results, the total N content was obtained. Further, the –NHX ratio was obtained from the XPS analysis. Thus, 100 mg catalyst was used as the standard, and correspondingly, the amounts of organic amines in the CN, HCN-TD and HCN-FD catalysts were 31.19, 3.96 and 5.85 mg, respectively. When CN, HCN-TD and HCN-FD acted as catalysts alone, trace PC was produced (entries 1–3). Thus, it was necessary to use additional cocatalyst to improve the catalytic activity by introducing nucleophilic groups in the following catalytic reactions. When the reaction was conducted with Bu4NBr cocatalyst, 25%, 35% and 46% PC yield were obtained (entries 4–6), because the synergistic interactions of introduced acid, existed Lewis base and nucleophilic reagent promoted the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. Also, the screenings of cocatalyst including KCl, KBr, KI, and Bu4NI were further discussed with HCN-FD catalyst. It was clearly observed that KX as nucleophilic component showed poor synergistic effect while Bu4NI displayed excellent performance (entries 7–10), which was ascribed to tributylamine from the decomposition of Bu4NI to activate CO2 [48]. And the catalytic activity was higher with Bu4NI cocatalyst than Bu4NBr, resulted from higher nucleophilicity of I −(entries 7–10). Further, PC showed superior catalytic yield with the increase of Bu4NI loading and 76% PC yield was obtained with 0.45 mmol Bu4NI (entry 11). Comparatively, single Bu4NI provided 31% PC yield (entry 12), illustrating the catalytic activity was significantly improved by the synergistic effect of nucleophile and HBD in HCN-FD. Hence, the bicomponent HCN-FD/Bu4NI were selected as catalytic system for the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxide. Effects of reaction parameters The influence of temperature, time and CO2 pressure on the PC yield was explored in Fig. 6 . The temperature had a positive impact on the PC yield in the range of 80–130 °C, because the effective collisions between reactant and catalyst became intense with the increase of temperature (Fig. 6A). Evidently, the PC yield remarkably increased from 30% to 98% with the temperature raised from 80 to 130 °C, meanwhile, the selectivity to the desired product of propylene carbonate was all maintained at 98%. When the temperature was 110 °C, 92% PC yield was obtained. Considering the viewpoint of energy saving, 110 °C was the optimum temperature for CO2 cycloaddition. With increasing the reaction time, gradual enhancement in the PC yield was obtained (Fig. 6B). Within 3 h reaction, HCN-FD/Bu4NI provided a moderate yield of 67% for the PC product. And moderate PO conversion was reached within 4–5 h. For 6 h reaction, the PC yield reached an excellent value of 92% and 98% selectivity. When the reaction time was elongated to 8 h, PC yield was not improved remarkably. Additionally, the dependence of the initial CO2 pressure on the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and PO was further tested (Fig. 6C). The CO2 pressure variation from 0.5 to 2.5 MPa induced the product yield a continuous increase and a descent at 3.0 MPa. The reaction system existed the solid catalyst, the bottom liquid phase with PO-rich, while the top gas phase with CO2-rich. The catalytic reaction mainly proceeded in the liquid phase with catalyst dispersion. In the low-pressure region of 0.5–2.5 MPa, it was favorable to form PC with the increase of CO2 concentration in liquid phase. In the high-pressure region (2.5–3.0 MPa), PC yield decreased attributed to the decreased PO phase as a reactant in the bottom with the increasing CO2 pressure into the gas phase [49]. Considering the PC yield and energy consumption, thus, 2.0 MPa CO2 was selected as the most suitable reaction pressure. Recyclability test and catalytic conversion of other epoxides The recycling stability of a catalyst was important factor for industrial applications. As summarized in Fig. 7 A, the yield and selectivity of PC were not significantly affected within 6 runs of catalytic reactions. However, in the 5th run, due to the inevitable weight loss during the wash and transfer process, PC yield dropped from 90 to 82%, and PC yield was achieved 87% again in the 6th run when 10 mg fresh HCN-FD was added in compensation of the catalyst loss. To illustrate the heterogeneity of the HCN-FD catalysis, a leaching test with hot filtrate supernatant was investigated and exhibited in revised Fig. 7B. The HCN-FD catalyst was removed by centrifugation when the catalytic reaction was performed for 3 h under the conditions of 110 °C and 2 MPa. As expected, the PC yield was almost no obvious increasing trend with the continuing time, indicating that the catalytic active sites almost did not leach in the reaction system. The leaching test further verified the heterogeneity of the HCN-FD catalyst. To further confirm the stability of the HCN-FD structure after recycles, FT-IR measurement was carried out (Fig. 7B). As expected, there was no difference between fresh and spent catalysts in the FT-IR spectra. Also, there were no obvious variations in XRD patterns (Fig. 7C), suggesting that HCN-FD was well preserved after reuse. These results proved the structure of HCN-FD catalyst was well maintained after the recycling processes. Subsequently, different substituent epoxides were investigated to couple with CO2 using HCN-FD/Bu4NI binary catalysts under the optimum condition shown in Fig. 8 . All the substrate epoxides could be smoothly converted to the corresponding cyclic carbonate. compared with PO conversion, BO provided slightly decreased activity at 78% resulted from its length of the carbon chain [50]. The excellent conversion activity of 99% was achieved with ECH substrate, which was ascribed to the effect of the electron-withdrawing Cl group to facilitate ring-opening. Likewise, BGE and AGE were converted to corresponding products at 98% and 90% conversions. Further, it is necessary to extend the time to obtain satisfactory conversion for the SO and CHO due to their bulky steric hindrance. For SO, the ring-opening was limited due to the conjugation between the benzene ring and epoxy group [50]. The internal CHO with bulkier steric hindrance presented the minimum conversion [51,52]. The scope versatility of various substituted epoxides demonstrated HCN-FD/Bu4NI catalysts were promising heterogeneous catalysts for the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides. Possible reaction mechanism According to the previous work [53,54], the CO2 cycloaddition was promoted by the synergetic effects of HBD and nucleophile. On one hand, epoxide was activated by HBD and the nucleophile could accelerate the ring-opening of epoxides. Simultaneously, CO2 could be activated by –NHX and Bu3N to polarize CO2 which was in agreement with the literature [28,48]. Moreover, little PC (3%) was formed because of the absence of nucleophilic Bu4NI when the HCN-FD was used alone, illustrating the nucleophilic played a crucial role in the catalytic cycloaddition reaction. 31% PC was obtained when the nucleophilic Bu4NI was employed alone, meanwhile, 76% PC was formed with HCN-FD/Bu4NI due to the synergistic effect between the HBD and nucleophilic. This result showed that HBD was also essential in the catalytic cycloaddition. To further study the catalytic mechanism, the in-situ FT-IR spectra were conducted to record the cycloaddition process for PC synthesis (Fig. 9 ). The characteristic absorption peak at 1790 cm−1 was detected, which was ascribed to the C = O of the PC product, suggesting that the formation of PC was proceeded efficiently by the cycloaddition of CO2 with PO [55]. Combined with previous work and our experiment results, the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxide over HCN-FD/Bu4NI mechanism was proposed in Scheme 1 . Firstly, PO was activated by HBD (–COOH and –OH), which bonded with O atom with epoxide by hydrogen bond, resulting in the polarization of the C–O bond (Step 1). Subsequently, I– from Bu4NI nucleophilic attacked the β-C atom of the activated PO to accelerate the ring-opening and oxyanion intermediate of C-I bond was formed (Step 2). Moreover, CO2 could be activated by –NHX and Bu3N to polarize CO2. Then, the intermediate interacted with activated CO2 (Step 3). Afterwards, the C − I bond was broken and PC was obtained via ring-closure, meanwhile, the catalyst HCN-FD was regenerated (Step 4). The Catalytic comparison of the present HCN-FD with reported CN catalysts Table 4 exhibited the comparisons with the catalytic performances of various modified CN materials for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to epoxides. To achieve the outstanding yield, a high temperature was necessary when the CN catalyst was used. Even, some catalysts showed superior activity with solvent DMF solvent (entries 1–4). Moreover, it required a long reaction time to achieve outstanding yield under the high temperature condition (entries 5–8). Notably, HCN-FD exhibited comparable activity at 110 °C without additional solvent. To compare the activity of different modified CN catalysts under various conditions, the TOF values were supplemented, which was calculated on the mass of produced cyclic carbonate per gram of catalyst per hour according to the literature [26] because the other modified CN catalysts could not provide the amounts of active sites. As a result, HCN-FD showed competitive activity in the CO2 conversion field with epoxides. Conclusions In summary, the hydrolyzed carbon nitride (HCN) was successfully prepared through treating by NaOH solution and freeze-drying (HCN-FD) method. In comparison with pristine CN, HCN-FD was proved to endow with more –COOH and –OH groups. Thus, the acidity of HCN-FD was significantly increased, confirmed by NH3-TPD measurement. In addition, HCN-FD exhibited efficiently catalytic activity with 92% of propylene carbonate yield in the presence of Bu4NI cocatalyst under the solvent- and metal-free conditions of 110 °C, 2.0 MPa CO2, 6 h. Furthermore, HCN-FD could be reused for 6 runs without obvious decrease, which demonstrated the advantage of structural stability of the catalyst. Thus, the as-synthesized HCN-FD was a promising heterogeneous catalyst candidate for CO2 cycloaddition with the virtue of eco-friendliness, simple synthesis process, efficiently catalytic activity, excellent performance in reusability and versatility. coredata.dc:description: With the aim of green chemistry and sustainable development, the coupling of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonate is an attractive and promising CO2 fixation without byproducts. Solvent- and metal-free heterogeneous catalysts offer an environmentally friendly and convenient separation alternative to traditional metal-based or homogeneous catalysts. Hence, hydrolyzed carbon nitride (HCN) was successfully synthesized via urea-derived carbon nitride (CN) hydrolyzed in NaOH solution and the freeze-drying (FD) method was adopted to obtain the HCN-FD catalyst. The composition and chemical properties of HCN-FD were thoroughly characterized by different analysis methods. The synergistic effects of hydrogen-bond donors of –COOH, –OH and –NHX in HCN-FD resulted in improved acidity sites characterized by NH3-TPD. Compared with CN, HCN-FD combined with tetrabutylammonium iodide cocatalyst displayed satisfactory catalytic performance in the CO2 cycloaddition due to more exposed active sites (–COOH, –OH and –NHX). Moreover, the recyclability and versatility of the HCN-FD catalyst were excellent in CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Thus, the HCN-FD catalyst was a potential candidate for the practical utilization of CO2 fixation due to its advantage of facile synthetic method, inexpensive raw material and environmental friendliness.
